page.title: 14MEDIA IN CHITTERNE
page.content: Radios and television are common, with many houses having more than one, but due to the position of Chitterne in a fold of the Downs, television reception is poor on some channels. The national daily newspapers are received in the village early in the day, coming by train to Salisbury and thence to Chitterne by road. Two locally employed youngsters then deliver them to the houses, for which they are paid Â£3 a week. There are two locally produced free journals; the fortnightly "Wylye Valley Life", concentrating on such items as poetry, local history, gardening, advertisements, meetings, etc., for which delivery boys are paid 1p. a copy, and a monthly single sheet newsletter of Chitterne, detailing items of village interest and news.
